title: How to help children of all ages deal with the clocks going back
text:
While many people will be grateful for the extra hour in bed when the clocks go back, parents of small children know that there’s no such seasonal treat. Last year, my daughter got so confused by a mere hour’s difference at bedtime that she staged a week-long 4.30am get-up protest.

It’s not her fault, says Professor Alice Gregory, a sleep researcher and author of two books on sleep. “This change in pattern may be particularly tricky for younger children who have an earlier chronotype, meaning that naturally they wake and sleep earlier.”

It also, doesn’t last forever. Dr Neil Stanley, a sleep expert and author, says that while the effects of the clock change can affect children in some instances...
